Award.AwardTitle: GP_EXTRA: Academic Year Pathways Research Experience Program (AY-PREP)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The United States needs to increase the number of awarded STEM undergraduate degrees by about 34% annually over current rates to meet the high demand for scientists and engineers in the workforce. Furthermore, the geosciences, which address complicated and dynamic Earth systems, are one of the least diverse STEM fields. Thus, recruiting, retaining, and preparing the next generation of diverse geoscientists remains a top priority if the U.S. is to remain a leader in the geosciences. This program, Academic Year Pathways Research Experience Program (AY-PREP), exposes students to a wide-range of career opportunities, emerging geoscience topics and environmental issues through hands-on activities and research experiences, and prepares them as future geoscientists through stratified mentoring and training of professional and soft skills.

The El Paso region, surrounded by the Franklin Mountains and within the Chihuahuan Desert, provides an ideal natural setting for exploring geoscience and environmental issues. Located at the southern end of the Rio Grande Rift and along the Rio Grande River, geology in El Paso features visible and easily accessible fault scarps, basin and range topography, and volcanoes. Furthermore, the El Paso area shares many environmental challenges with our border city, Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, including limited fresh water resources, elevated soil salinity in agriculture, and dust and air pollution issues. The University of Texas at El Paso (UTEP) is building upon past, successful efforts to broaden participation in STEM, as well as leverage UTEP's unique demographic (80% Hispanic) and research infrastructure, to develop a comprehensive program that recruits, retains, and prepares the next generation of diverse geoscientists to earn advance degrees and/or enter the workforce: Academic Year Pathways Research Experience Program (AY-PREP). The program includes: 1) an academic year interdisciplinary research experience for a cohort of six undergraduates per year, 2) weekly seminars and workshops to expose students to cutting-edge research, graduate programs, and career opportunities, and prepare students for technical, professional, and soft skills; 3) a stratified mentoring program; 4) opportunities for the cohort to participate in the deployment of a seismic field experiment; and 5) a two-week summer bridge camp that brings together incoming AY-PREP students, undergraduate students, senior high school students, and pre-service teachers. The summer camp includes field trips to the Jemez Critical Zone Observatory in New Mexico, integration of IRIS Education and Outreach programming, training on geophysical/geochemical instrumentation and sensor technology, and the synthesis of large datasets that serve as a foundation for undergraduate student research projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goals for the Academic Year Pathways Research Experience Program (AY-PREP) project were to develop a comprehensive program, based on an academic year research program, that recruits, retains, and prepares the next generation of diverse geoscientists. Our specific objectives include: 1) exposing students to research, 2) exposing students to a field experience, 3) preparing students for advanced degrees, 4) preparing students for entry into the workforce, and 5) building a community of students, mentors, and pre-service teachers to develop a sense of belonging.

Throughout the years, we fulfilled all these goals, always focusing on enhancing the students' experiences obtained from their regular classwork and research efforts. Being part of our research workshops allowed students to meet their classmates in a more informal setting creating a strong cohort of students.  This allowed students to work closely together for advice and collaboration and created a strong peer-mentor environment. Furthermore, we fostered the peer-mentoring environment with active learning to create a network of students that was integrated into department activities and helped students be more confident when attending meetings and conferences. Our workshops and seminars provided additional guidance on graduate programs and career opportunities and has allowed students to improve their soft skills. Our volunteer graduate students attended many of our different activities and served as a resource for teaching our younger students. Senior undergraduate students also served as peer-mentors to their classmates such that most of the work done during our workshops took place in pairs or groups. 

Our students had the opportunity of participating in research projects under the supervision of many faculty members of the Geological Sciences department in a variety of Earth Science topics, from seismology to geochemistry to hydrology. This helped our students to focus on their interests and continue their education on their preferred field. Over the course of the project, we funded 28 undergraduate students to conduct research for an average of two semesters (although we had a couple of students funded for six semesters), five undergraduate scholars (attending our workshops but funded by other sources or unfunded), eight graduate students (partially funded to attend a national conference) and seven preservice teachers funded to participate in our summer camp. A total of 41 students have participated in our program. 19 have earned their bachelor's degree while 9 are still in progress. One has completed their masters, while 5 remain in MS or Ph.D. programs. Some others have finished their education and are working in industry.
